TextView.android:text: Social engineering is the art of manipulating people so they give up confidential information; including passwords, social security numbers, or bank information. Common social engineering attacks include: (1) Emails looking as though they are from friends, family, or businesses. Usually containing a link or a download. May be appealing to peopleâ€™s desire to donate or help those in need. - to prevent this: Google the organization from which the email came to see if the website/email used is the real one or if it is friend or family contact that person directly through a means you know is secure to see if they are the ones who sent the email. (2) Over the phone - similar to email. If you receive a phone call saying that you have won a prize or if it is a person or organization asking for money. (3) Passwords should be strong: at least 15 characters, at least 1 special character, at least 1 number, and at least 1 uppercase letter.

Social engineering facts: (1) One in five American senior citizen is a victim of online financial fraud, costing more than $2.6 billion per year (Willis, 2015). (2) Senior citizens who are identity theft victims suffer devastating effects (Jones, 2001): (a) Loss of all their life savings, (b) Feelings of shame for being victims, (c) Decreased self-confidence, and (d) Exacerbated illnesses to include premature death.
